channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Middle East Crisis: As Ramadan Nears Its End, Relief Remains Elusive in Gaza
item.description: Cease-fire talks are sputtering and widespread hunger persists, even as the pace of the Israel-Hamas war slows.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinian women preparing traditional cookies for the end of the holy fasting month of Ramadan, in Deir al Balah, Gaza, on Monday.

item.title: A Drone Strike in Odesa, Ukraine, Shatters a Family’s Life
item.description: Serhii Haidarzhy’s wife and son were killed when their apartment block was hit. He and their daughter survived. The tragedy has become a symbol in Ukraine of the war’s terrible toll on civilians.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Oksana Parafeniuk
item.media:credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yelyzaveta Gaidarzhi, 2, wakes up from a nap in Odesa, Ukraine, last month. Yelyzaveta lost her mother Anna Gaidarzhi, and her 4-month-old brother Tymofii in a Russian drone strike.

item.title: Switzerland’s Climate Shortfalls Violate Human Rights, European Court Rules
item.description: But the European Court of Human Rights ruled as inadmissible two other climate-related attempts to hold governments accountable.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Emma Bubola
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Supporters for the group of older women bringing a climate-related lawsuit against Switzerland at the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg, France, on Tuesday.

item.title: Simon Harris Is Set to Become Ireland’s Youngest Prime Minister. Who Is He?
item.description: After a swift political rise, the 37-year-old is set to become Ireland’s premier on Tuesday. But his time as head of the government could be short.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Simon Harris, the leader of the Fine Gael party, in Ireland last month. Mr. Harris has “always been hungry” for his new role, a politics professor said.

item.title: Xi of China Meets With Russia’s Foreign Minister, Reaffirming Ties
item.description: The visit came days after the U.S. threatened new sanctions against Chinese companies if they aided Russia’s war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Russian Foreign Ministry Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo released by the Russian Foreign Ministry of Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov in Beijing, where he also met with his Chinese counterpart.

item.title: Canada Wants to Regulate Online Content. Critics Say It Goes Too Far.
item.description: A bill introduced by the Canadian government to safeguard against online harms has stirred opposition from free speech advocates.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Arif Virani, the justice minister and attorney general of Canada, speaking about the Online Harms Act during a news conference in Canada in February.

item.title: Iran Smuggles Arms to West Bank, Officials Say, to Foment Unrest With Israel
item.description: The covert operation, described by U.S., Iranian and Israeli officials, is heightening concerns that Iran is seeking to turn the West Bank into a flashpoint in its shadow war with Israel.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi, Ronen Bergman and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: A damaged building in Syria. Airstrikes in Syria last week targeted units from Iran’s Revolutionary Guards Corps overseeing smuggling, according to officials.

item.title: Surviving Daily Life in Ukraine’s Frontline Villages
item.description: As war beat a path through southern and eastern Ukraine, most of the population fled. But other residents have hunkered down, unable — or unwilling — to leave.
item.dc:creator: Emile Ducke, Oleksandr Naselenko and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: SELYDOVE, Ukraine - November 17, 2023. Rescue workers look through the ruble of a residential building heavily damaged by a Russian missile strike in the eastern Ukrainian town of Selydove in the Donetsk region.

item.title: U.N. Inspectors Say Nuclear Plant in Ukraine Was Struck by Drones
item.description: The watchdog agency did not attribute blame, but its head said the strikes at the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant “significantly increase the risk of a major nuclear accident.”
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant seen in the distance from Nikopol, Ukraine, last summer.

item.title: Nearly 100 Die After Boat Sinks Off Coast of Mozambique
item.description: Some of the victims were en route to a fair and others were fleeing for fear of being affected by a cholera outbreak, a local official said.
item.dc:creator: Armando Tivane and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: TVM, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A screen shot from a video on the Mozambique national broadcaster, TVM, showing the boat that sank on Sunday after it was brought back to shore.

item.title: Rwanda Marks Anniversary of 1994 Genocide
item.description: The Central African country is marking the anniversary of a monthslong rampage by militiamen that killed some 800,000 people.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: President Paul Kagame of Rwanda and his wife, Jeannette Kagame, lighting a remembrance flame on Sunday in Kigali as part of commemorations of the 30th anniversary of the 1994 Rwandan genocide.

item.title: Takeaways From the Vatican’s Document on Human Dignity
item.description: The document restated the Roman Catholic Church’s rejection of abortion, gender fluidity and transition surgery.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis’ inclusive message in the Roman Catholic Church has a limit: Catholic doctrine.

item.title: South Korea’s Election Is About ‘Gladiator Politics’
item.description: This week’s parliamentary elections are widely seen as a referendum on both President Yoon Suk Yeol and his archrival, Lee Jae-myung, the opposition leader.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Lee Jae-myung of the Democratic Party and Yoon Suk Yeol of the People Power Party during the presidential election campaign in Seoul in 2022.

item.title: Homecoming
item.description: A single photo captures a moment of setback for families who had tried for a better life.
item.media:credit: Elise Blanchard for The New York Times

item.title: Should Alcoholic Beverages Have Cancer Warning Labels?
item.description: Ireland will require them starting in 2026, and there are nascent efforts elsewhere to add more explicit labeling about the health risks of drinking.
item.dc:creator: Ted Alcorn

item.title: The U.S. Urgently Needs a Bigger Grid. Here’s a Fast Solution.
item.description: A rarely used technique to upgrade old power lines could play a big role in fixing one of the largest obstacles facing clean energy, two reports found.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:description: Replacing existing power lines with cables made from state-of-the-art materials could roughly double the capacity of the electric grid in many parts of the country.

item.title: At UN Court, Germany Fights Allegations of Aiding Genocide in Gaza
item.description: Nicaragua has accused Germany over its provision of military and financial aid to Israel. Germany said the case had “no basis in fact or law.”
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons and Erika Solomon
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Robin Van Lonkhuijsen/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Members of Germany’s delegation, Tania von Uslar-Gleichen and Christian J. Tams, during hearings at the International Court of Justice in The Hague on Tuesday.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Eclipse day in North America.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times

item.title: New Method That Pinpoints Wood’s Origin May Curb Illegal Timber
item.description: The study could help identify wood from Russia, which has been banned by many countries because of the war.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Nazaryan
item.media:description: Timber being moved down the Angara River in the Krasnoyarsk region, in Russia.

item.title: German Business Is Tangled in Red Tape
item.description: Companies in Germany complain that the demands of bureaucracy are costing them time and money that would be better spent building their businesses.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Roderick Aichinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Germany, a spate of new rules means that Technotherm Heat Treatment Group must prove it complies with the same standards it has been certified as reaching since 2012.

item.title: Active Fighting Subsides in Gaza, but the War Is Not Over, Officials Say
item.description: Israeli troops have left southern Gaza, and some Palestinians returned to the area, where there was a sense of horror at the scope of destruction.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Damaged buildings in Khan Younis on Monday, after Israel pulled its ground forces out of the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Iran Pardons 4 Environmental Activists for Eid al-Fitr, Lawyer Says
item.description: Two have been freed so far, state media said. They were among eight arrested in 2018 on charges of spying, which they have denied.
item.dc:creator: Yonette Joseph and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:description: The entrance to Evin prison in Tehran.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: A Total Solar Eclipse
item.description: Also, the Vatican said gender changes amount to an affront.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Meghan Dhaliwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Spectators gasped in Mazatlán, Mexico.

item.title: Ex-Ecuadorean Vice President, Arrested at Mexican Embassy, Is Hospitalized
item.description: The former vice president, Jorge Glas, had taken pills, the police said, and was taken to a hospital. He had taken refuge at the embassy after being accused of corruption.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Thalíe Ponce
item.media:description: Jorge Glas, a former vice president of Ecuador, in Quito, the capital, in 2018.

item.title: For Nicaragua, International Case Against Germany Is Déjà Vu
item.description: Nicaragua’s accusation against Germany in the International Court of Justice comes 40 years after the country filed a claim against the United States in the same court.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Ambassador Carlos J. Argüello Gómez of Nicaragua, center, waiting on Monday for the start of a hearing at The Hague.

item.title: ‘Hardest Geezer’ Finishes Running the Length of Africa
item.description: Russ Cook of Britain overcame danger in a year of running from South Africa to Tunisia.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: Russ Cook crossed the finish line in Cape Angela, Tunisia, on Sunday after running the length of Africa. He completed the journey in a little under a year after setting off from Cape Agulhas, South Africa.

item.title: Yair Lapid Calls for Close Ties With U.S. in Visit to Washington
item.description: In the wake of President Biden’s recent warning to Israel to stop the killing of civilians in Gaza, Yair Lapid said the two countries “need to maintain this friendship.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Israeli opposition leader Yair Lapid speaks to reporters after meeting with US Secretary of State Antony Blinken at the US State Department on Monday.

item.title: Gazans Find Khan Younis ‘Unrecognizable’ After Israeli Withdrawal
item.description: “You build a home corner by corner, stone by stone,” said one man who came back to Khan Younis. “And in the end, with a press of a button, it is reduced to rubble.”
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: A Palestinian family rides on a cart through Khan Younis, Gaza, on Monday.

item.title: PFAS ‘Forever Chemicals’ Are Pervasive in Water Worldwide, Study Finds
item.description: A global survey found harmful levels even in water samples taken far any obvious source of contamination.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa
item.media:description: The study “sets off alarm bells,” one of the authors said.

item.title: Israel’s Account of World Central Kitchen Strike Raises Wider Legal Questions, Experts Say
item.description: The events that led to the deaths of seven World Central Kitchen workers suggest that there could be problems with the protocols used by the Israeli military, according to legal experts and aid organizations.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A vehicle with the logo of World Central Kitchen that was damaged in an Israeli strike in Deir al Balah, Gaza. The Israeli military says a string of errors led to the fatal attack.

item.title: Israel’s withdrawal suggests the war has entered a new phase.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: A Palestinian woman walks past damaged buildings in Khan Younis on Monday, after Israel pulled its ground forces out of the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Vatican Says Gender Change and Surrogacy Are Threats to Human Dignity
item.description: The statement is likely to be embraced by conservatives and stir consternation among L.G.B.T.Q. advocates who fear it will be used as a cudgel against transgender people.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis at his weekly general audience in St. Peter’s Square in Vatican City last week.

item.title: Nicaragua Is Taking Germany to ICJ Over Supplying Arms to Israel
item.description: A new case before the International Court of Justice argues that the German government is furthering genocide in the Gaza war.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Judges and delegates at the International Court of Justice in The Hague on Monday.

item.title: Yellen Sees ‘More Work to Do’ as China Talks End With No Breakthrough
item.description: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen was warmly received in China, but it was evident that the level of trust between the two sides does not run deep.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen with Premier Li Qiang of China at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Sunday.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Israel says it withdrew troops from southern Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik

item.title: Could Ecuador’s Diplomatic Spat With Mexico Be a Boon for Noboa?
item.description: Analysts believe that President Daniel Noboa’s re-election hopes are what motivated the arrest of an Ecuadorean politician taking refuge at the Mexican Embassy.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:description: Military and police officers in Quito, Ecuador, on Saturday.

item.title: Israel Withdraws Troops From Southern Gaza as War Hits 6-Month Mark
item.description: With the conflict at an apparent impasse, international mediators were gathering in Cairo with hopes of brokering a temporary cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Patrick Kingsley, Ephrat Livni and Matt Stevens
item.media:description: Khan Younis on Sunday. Israel said it had pulled its forces from the southern Gaza city.

item.title: At Rally for Hostages, Nadler Is Booed After Calling for Gaza Aid
item.description: A speech by Jerrold Nadler, a long-serving Jewish Democrat and supporter of Israel, was met with a mixed response at a New York rally calling for the release of hostages in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Liset Cruz
item.media:description: Representative Jerrold Nadler, Democrat of New York, spoke during a demonstration calling for the release of hostages held in Gaza.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Israel Pulls Some Troops from Southern Gaza
item.description: Also, Mexico and Nicaragua severed diplomatic relations with Ecuador.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Palestinians returning to Khan Younis after Israel said it had pulled a division of soldiers from the city.

item.title: Princess Reema, Saudi Ambassador, Navigates Rough Waters in Washington
item.description: The Saudi ambassador to the United States, the daughter of a storied figure in the kingdom’s diplomacy, is trying to steer relations at a difficult time.
item.dc:creator: Kate Kelly
item.category: Reema bint Bandar bin Sultan, Princess of Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: Princess Reema Bandar al-Saud is the daughter of Prince Bandar bin Sultan, who was one of the most powerful diplomats in Washington. She has taken up his old role at a critical time.

item.title: Gazans Are Turning to This Wild Plant for Survival
item.description: Palestinians have long gathered and cooked khobeza, a spinach-like wild plant that sprouts after rains. Now, it has become a lifeline.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Bilal Shbair
item.media:description: Selling khobeza leaves in Rafah, in southern Gaza, in February. The plant is making up an outsize portion of many Gazans’ diets by providing a lower-cost way to blunt hunger.

item.title: A C.I.A. Black Site Remains a Touchy Subject for Lithuania
item.description: Despite rulings in European courts saying the Baltic country was home to a secret prison, the issue has been shrouded in official secrecy in a nation closely allied with the United States.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Andrej Vasilenko for The New York Times
item.media:description: The former C.I.A. site, code-named Site Violet, in Antaviliai, Lithuania.

item.title: Japan and US Seek to Strengthen Ties as Kishida Visits
item.description: Hovering over a state visit to Washington is the possibility of a swing in American foreign policy if Donald Trump returns to the White House.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Biden with Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan at the NATO headquarters in Brussels in 2022.

item.title: Peter Pellegrini Wins Slovakia’s Presidential Election
item.description: The victory for Peter Pellegrini, an ally of Slovakia’s populist prime minister, strengthens Central Europe’s ties to Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Peter Pellegrini casting his ballot in Bratislava in the first round of Slovakia’s presidential election in March.

item.title: Another Israeli Hostage’s Body Recovered, the Death Angering His Family
item.description: Like the families of other hostages, they are outraged that the Israeli government has yet to reach a deal to halt the fighting and bring home loved ones held in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Anna Betts
item.media:description: A March protest in Tel Aviv demanding the release of the Oct. 7 hostages. At center, a woman holds a poster of Elad Katzir, whose body was recovered Friday by the Israeli military.

item.title: Who Is Jorge Glas, an Ecuadorean Politician Arrested at Mexico’s Embassy?
item.description: A former vice president of Ecuador, Jorge Glas had been convicted of bribery in two separate cases. He had fled to the Mexican Embassy in Quito after facing more embezzlement charges.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Ecuador’s former vice president, Jorge Glas, after his release from prison in Quito, Ecuador, in 2022.

item.title: The Israeli hostage whose body was returned Saturday had spoken of feeling unsafe.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Maya Palty, left, rallied for her relative Elad Katzir in January. Mr. Katzir had deep roots in Nir Oz, the kibbutz in southern Israel where he was born and from which he was abducted on Oct. 7.

item.title: New England Journal of Medicine Ignored Nazi Atrocities, Historians Find
item.description: The New England Journal of Medicine published an article condemning its own record during World War II.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Nazaryan
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Fox Photos Ltd./Sydney Morning Herald, via Alamy
item.media:description: Nazi doctors and scientists on trial at Nuremberg in 1947 for human experiments, murders and other atrocities during the Holocaust.

item.title: Israel Says It Recovered Body of Elad Katzir, an Oct. 7 Hostage
item.description: Elad Katzir lived near the border with the Gaza Strip. His sister said Israel’s government should have done more to get him back alive.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Supporters held posters of Elad Katzir during a protest in Tel Aviv in February.

item.title: Russian Missiles Hit Kharkiv, Killing at Least 6
item.description: The latest assault on the eastern city killed at least seven people, local authorities said. As Kyiv waits on American aid, Moscow has stepped up bombardments, including using modified “glide bombs.”
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A bomb crater at the scene of an overnight attack in Kharkiv, eastern Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: Eclipse Mania
item.description: There’s still reason to get excited, even if you’re not convinced by the hype.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Iran vows revenge at a funeral for commanders killed in an Israeli airstrike.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi, Eric Schmitt and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trucks carrying the coffins of seven Iranian commanders killed in an Israeli airstrike in Syria passed by mourners in Tehran on Friday.

item.title: Trudeau Gives Preview of Canada’s Federal Budget, Breaking Tradition
item.description: Breaking with Canadian tradition, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has been crisscrossing the country announcing measures from the April 16 budget in advance.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Jeff Mcintosh/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau at a housing announcement in Calgary on Friday.

item.title: Gaza War Turns Spotlight on Long Pipeline of U.S. Weapons to Israel
item.description: President Biden sends arms to Israel under an Obama-era $38 billion aid agreement that runs until 2026. Israel’s purchases include the types of bombs dropped in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
item.media:description: An Israeli Blackhawk, an American-made helicopter, during a drill in northern Israel in February.

item.title: Pardoned for Serving in Ukraine, They Return to Russia to Kill Again
item.description: Recruiting convicts for its army has given Russia a manpower advantage. But it is backfiring in tragic ways when former inmates are pardoned and return home to commit new crimes.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Russian military recruitment billboard saying, “Heroes are not born, they are made,” last year in Ulan-Ude, Russia. Veterans who survive the front line return to Russia as heroes with an elevated status in society.

item.title: Mexico Breaks Diplomatic Ties With Ecuador After Jorge Glas Arrest
item.description: Jorge Glas, a former vice president, had taken refuge at the Mexican Embassy in Ecuador’s capital. Mexico’s president called his arrest a violation of international law.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon, Isabella Kwai and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:description: Ecuadorean police officers entered the Mexican Embassy in Quito on Friday night to arrest Ecuador’s former vice president.

item.title: 30 Years After Rwandan Genocide, Ruler Holds Tight Grip
item.description: Thirty years after a devastating genocide, Rwanda has made impressive gains. But ethnic divisions persist under an iron-fisted president who has ruled for just as long.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: President Paul Kagame of Rwanda in 2021. The architect of the country’s stunning transformation, he achieved it with harsh methods that would normally attract international condemnation.

item.title: Why Time Is Running Out Across the Maldives’ Lovely Little Islands
item.description: Global tourism brought a modern economy to the country’s thousand islands. For many Maldivians, the teeming capital beckons.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli, Maahil Mohamed and Elke Scholiers
item.media:description: Teenagers gathering to watch the sun set in Nolhivaranfaru, a remote island in the Maldives.

item.title: More Myanmar Political Prisoners Are Dying in Military Prisons
item.description: The country’s military rulers have signaled a new wave of detentions and, rights groups say, conditions for existing prisoners have deteriorated.
item.dc:creator: Caleb Quinley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A bus carrying prisoners exiting Insein prison in Yangon, Myanmar, in January. The junta has said it will release thousands of prisoners, but rights groups warn that any freedom is likely to be temporary.

item.title: U.S. Seeks ‘Results’ After Israel Promises More Gaza Aid Routes
item.description: World leaders welcomed the shift by an Israel facing increasing pressure, but they stressed that the measure of success would be whether enough trucks get in to ease the humanitarian crisis.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd, Raja Abdulrahim and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: A makeshift tent camp for displaced people in Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip on Thursday.

item.title: Senior Tory MP William Wragg Admits Sharing Colleagues’ Private Data on Grindr
item.description: William Wragg said he had been scared that a man he met on the Grindr dating app had “compromising things” on him, and apologized for causing “hurt.”
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: U.K. Parliament/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An undated photo released by the British Parliament of William Wragg, a conservative lawmaker, who admitted that he had given the phone numbers of fellow members of Parliament to someone he met on Grindr.

item.title: Iran Vows Revenge at Funeral for Commanders Killed in Israeli Airstrike
item.description: The Israeli airstrike this week in Damascus that killed seven Iranian commanders was an unusually harsh blow, and officials say Iran is determined to respond, raising fears of a war.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi, Eric Schmitt and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral procession Tehran on Friday for seven Iranian military commanders killed by an Israeli airstrike in Syria on Monday.

item.title: Is Bird Flu Coming to People Next? Are We Ready?
item.description: Unlike the coronavirus, the H5N1 virus has been studied for years. Vaccines and treatments are available should they ever become necessary.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Rachel Bujalski for The New York Times
item.media:description: Avian influenza, which is often fatal in birds, surprised officials when it was found in dairy cows in multiple states.
